cpu_types.text:
CPU (Central Processing Unit): The general term for a general-purpose computer. Typically run at high clock speeds (GHz range).
MCU (Microcontroller Unit): The same base architecture as a CPu complete computer system on a single chip, including CPU, memory, and I/O peripherals. For example, the STM32F4. MCUs usually operate at much lower clock speeds (MHz range) compared to CPUs, focusing on low power and real-time control.
DSP (Digital Signal Processor): A specialized processor optimized for digital signal processing operations like filtering, FFT, and audio/video processing. For example, Texas Instruments TMS320C6000.

paw3395.text: High-performance gaming optical sensor with 30,000 DPI capability

isa.text:
Instruction Set Architecture

The set of instructions that a processor can execute

IC.text:
Integrated Circuit

A set of electronic circuits on a small flat piece of semiconductor material (usually silicon). An IC can contain billions of transistors, resistors, and capacitors working together to perform complex functions.

electronic.text:
It's important to define the distinction between electrical and electronic.

- Electrical: means "current flowing through wires", for example motors, simple wirings and lighting.
- Electronic: means "current flowing through active components that perform computation", like diodes, transistor and ultimately computers.

cpu_non_triviality.text: This is not a trivial thing: considering that integrated circuits are machines, the bare fact that a general purpose machine is manufacturable makes it so that everyone can have a computer for their own needs at low cost: make 100 CPUs and program them differently. I cannot overstate how much this changed the world.
